text: Faith is a strange thing; it often conceals itself in such a way that we can neither see nor find it.
author: Ole Hallesby

text: Such a faith as this sees its own need, acknowledges its own helplessness, goes to Jesus, tells Him just how bad things are and leaves everything with Him.
author: Ole Hallesby

text: Unbelief is something very different from doubt. Unbelief is an attribute of the will and consists in the refusal to believe, that is, refusal to see one's own need, acknowledge one's helplessness, go to Jesus and speak candidly and confidently with Him about one's own sin and distress. Doubt, on the other hand, is anguish, a pain, a weakness, which at times affects our faith. We could therefore call it faith-distress, faith-anguish, faith-suffering, faith-tribulation.
author: Ole Hallesby

text: The man seemed to sense the seriousness of Jesus' words and exclaimed distress, "I believe; help Thou mine unbelief!" Here we have a typical example of doubting faith.
author: Ole Hallesby

text: He himself condemns his doubt as unbelief. That is what sincere faith always does; it judges itself strictly and umercifully.
author: Ole Hallesby

text: We can begin by telling Him about our doubts and our weak faith. This makes it easier for us, and we can pray more confidently.

text: Primal Leadership is a book that explores the concept of emotional intelligence (EI) in leadership. It argues that EI is a key factor in effective leadership and that leaders who are high in EI are better able to create a positive and productive work environment and achieve success.
author: * ASIN:

text: The book is written by Daniel Goleman, Richard Boyatzis, and Annie McKee, who are experts in the fields of leadership, EI, and organizational behavior. They begin by explaining the concept of EI and how it differs from traditional measures of intelligence, such as IQ. They then introduce the six areas of EI that are essential for effective leadership: self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, social skills, and understanding and managing groups.
author: * ASIN:

text: The authors argue that self-awareness is the foundation of EI and that leaders who are self-aware are better able to understand their own emotions and how they affect their behavior. They are also better able to understand the impact of their actions on others. Self-regulation, on the other hand, refers to the ability to manage one's own emotions and impulses. Leaders who are able to self-regulate are better able to handle stress and remain level-headed in difficult situations.
author: * ASIN:

text: Motivation is another important aspect of EI. Leaders who are motivated are able to use their emotions to drive action and achieve goals. They are also better able to inspire and motivate their team members. Empathy is the ability to understand and respond to the emotions of others. Leaders who are empathetic are better able to build strong relationships with their team members and create a positive work environment.
author: * ASIN:

text: Social skills are also important for effective leadership. These include the ability to communicate effectively, collaborate with others, and build and maintain relationships. Understanding and managing groups is the final aspect of EI that the authors discuss. Leaders who are able to effectively lead and influence groups of people are better able to achieve success in their organizations.
author: * ASIN:

text: Throughout the book, the authors provide real-world examples and case studies to illustrate the importance of EI in leadership. They also offer practical advice and tips for leaders who want to improve their EI. For example, they suggest that leaders should practice mindfulness and self-reflection in order to become more self-aware. They also recommend that leaders should seek feedback from others in order to understand how they are perceived and to identify areas for improvement.
author: * ASIN:

text: Overall, Primal Leadership is a thought-provoking and insightful book that provides a new perspective on leadership and the importance of EI. It is a must-read for anyone interested in leadership and organizational behavior. The book provides a comprehensive understanding of how emotional intelligence can be used in leadership, and how it can help leaders to create a positive and productive work environment, and achieve success

text: SLOW PRODUCTIVITY A philosophy for organizing knowledge work efforts in a sustainable and meaningful manner, based on the following three principles: 1. Do fewer things. 2. Work at a natural pace. 3. Obsess over quality.
author: Cal Newport

text: None of these answers included specific goals to meet, or performance measures that could differentiate between doing a job well versus badly. When quantity was mentioned, it tended to be in the general sense that more is always better. (Productivity is "working all the time," explained an exhausted postdoc named Soph.) As I read through more of my surveys, an unsettling revelation began to emerge: for all of our complaining about the term, knowledge workers have no agreed-upon definition of what "productivity" even means.
author: Cal Newport

text: The first such idea is the power of appealing alternatives. As Michael Pollan summarizes in an insightful 2003 article about Slow Food, by the 1980s Carlo Petrini had become "dismayed by the hangdog dourness of his comrades on the left." There's a personal satisfaction in grimly pointing out the flaws in a system, but sustainable change, Petrini came to believe, requires providing people with an enjoyable and life-affirming alternative. Petrini didn't simply write a sharply worded op-ed about the corruptive forces of McDonald's, he instead promoted an appealing new relationship with food that would make fast food seem self-evidently vulgar. "Those who suffer for others do more damage to humanity than those who enjoy themselves," Petrini explained.
author: Cal Newport

text: Strive to reduce your obligations to the point where you can easily imagine accomplishing them with time to spare. Leverage this reduced load to more fully embrace and advance the small number of projects that matter most.
author: Cal Newport

text: My goal in this chapter is to persuade you not to give up on this aspirational vision of engineered simplicity. It is possible in most modern work settings, if you're willing to be creative-and per-haps, at times, even radical—in how you think about selecting and organizing your work.
author: Cal Newport

text: In knowledge work, when you agree to a new commitment, be it a minor task or a large project, it brings with it a certain amount of ongoing administrative overhead: back-and-forth email threads needed to gather information, for example, or meetings scheduled to synchronize with your collaborators. This overhead tax activates as soon as you take on a new responsibility. As your to-do list grows, so does the total amount of overhead tax you're paying. Because the number of hours in the day is fixed, these administrative chores will take more and more time away from your core work, slowing down the rate at which these objectives are accom-plished.
author: Cal Newport

text: fires, you enjoy a more expansive sense of experimentation and pos-sibility. Maybe you're able to identify a clever new business strat-egy, devise an elegant algorithm, or come up with a bold advertising campaign that would have eluded you in a more fragmented state of attention. There are boring physiological and neurological explanations for this effect involving the mind-constricting impacts of cortisol when your schedule becomes unrealistically full, or the time required to excite rich semantic connections among your brain's neurons. But we don't need science to convince us of something that we've all experienced directly: our brains work better when we're not rushing.
author: Cal Newport

text: Assuming you're not a tenured mathematics professor, the specific actions Andrew Wiles took to simplify his workload are likely not that relevant. What is useful for our discussion, however, is the general approach he deployed. To prepare himself to focus on a single large and meaningful project, Wiles limited large pursuits and commitments that would compete for his time. Crucially, he was systematic in this reduction. He didn't resolve, in some generic fashion, to try to take on less; he instead put in place specific rules (e.g., no conferences), habits (e.g., work from home as much as possible), and even ploys (e.g., trickling out his already completed research) —all directed toward minimizing the number of big items tugging at his attention.
author: Cal Newport

text: This first proposition suggests that you follow Andrew Wiles's example and implement a systematic plan for limiting significant commitments in your own professional life. There are many ways to pursue this goal. In the strategies that follow, I'll outline a specific approach that I've found to be particularly useful: applying limits at different scales of work at the same time, from your overarching missions, to your ongoing projects, to your daily goals.
author: Cal Newport

text: still feel compatible with slow productivity, especially if I'm careful to control it (see the next proposition for more on that), but, if I'm honest, I'm nostalgic for the simplicity of two, and salivate over the idea of one. Moving in the other direction, it's hard to maintain five or more missions without the feeling you're drowning in unavoidable work. This might sound like a lot of objectives to take on, but it's easier than you might imagine to allow your commitment count to grow over time. My friend Jenny Blake, for example, writes in her 2022 book, Free Time, about how her small consulting and training business kept expanding until, one day, exhausted by the demands of work, she looked up and realized she was supporting more than ten different sources of income, which she described as "legacies from years of experimenting." No amount of clever time management or streamlining tactics can keep the work required to maintain ten missions tractable.
author: Cal Newport

text: To gain this credibility, I recommend, at first, when considering a new project, you estimate how much time it will require and then go find that time and schedule it on your calendar. Block off the hours as you would for a meeting. If you're unable to find enough blank spaces in your schedule in the near future to easily fit the work, then you don't have enough time for it. Either decline the project, or cancel something else to make room. The power of this approach is that you're dealing with the reality of your time, not a gut feeling about how busy you are at the moment.
author: Cal Newport

text: We've arrived at the smallest scale of work that we'll consider for our limiting strategies: the projects you decide to make progress on during the current day. My recommendation here is simple: work on at most one project per day. To clarify, I don't intend for this single daily project to be your only work for the day. You'll likely also have meetings to attend, emails to answer, and administrative nonsense to subdue (we'll talk more about these smaller tasks in the upcoming proposition about containing the small). But when it comes to expending efforts on important, bigger initiatives, stay focused on just one target per day.
author: Cal Newport

text: As I later pivoted my writing away from student issues, the autopilot schedule faded into the background as I focused on more office-specific tools, like time blocking and email protocols. Re-cently, however, as the administrative demands of my own job continue to expand, I've begun once again to experiment with this strategy. In the context of knowledge work, it turns out, autopilot schedules provide an effective means to contain tasks. Instead of setting regular times each week for completing school assignments, you can set times for accomplishing specific categories of regularly occurring tasks. A freelancer, for example, might schedule sending invoices for Monday morning, while a professor might schedule reviewing grant reports for Fridays, right after lunch. Once you get used to accomplishing a specific type of task at the same times on the same days, the overhead required for their execution plummets.
author: Cal Newport

text: A key refinement to support this task-centric version of autopilot scheduling is to leverage rituals and locations. If you can connect a regularly recurring task block to a specific location, perhaps paired with a little ritual that helps initiate your efforts, you're more likely to fall into a regular rhythm of accomplishing this work.
author: Cal Newport

text: AVOID TASK ENGINES It's natural to focus on taming the pile of tasks you've already built up. Equally effective containment strategies, however, can be found upstream in your workflow, before obligations are generated in the first place. The following such strategy, for example, can be surprisingly effective in reducing your task burden: When selecting new projects, assess your options by the number of weekly requests, questions, or small chores you expect the project to generate. Prioritize options that minimize this number. Most people focus on the difficulty of a project, or the total amount of time it might re-quire. But once you understand the havoc wreaked by an overstuffed to-do list, it makes sense that the task footprint of a project should be taken just as seriously.
author: Cal Newport

text: In the short term, all of this costs money. If your company is new, or your income still modest, it can be unnerving to see a nontrivial percent of these earnings go right back out the door. But in the long term, this off-loading of the small can provide the mental space needed to make the types of large breakthroughs, and produce the type of value, that will make these monthly expenses suddenly seem trivial in scope. Don't spend more than you can afford. But recognize that a practitioner of slow productivity cannot afford to spend nothing.
author: Cal Newport

text: The solution the Broad Institute came up with wasn't new, but instead an adaptation of a technique common in the world of industrial manufacturing: switching the flow of their genetic sequencing process from "push" to "pull" In a push-based process, each stage pushes work onward to the next as soon as it's done. In a pull-based process, by contrast, each stage pulls in new work only when i's ready for it. At Broad, this pull methodology was implemented in a simple manner. Each stage maintained a tray to place the completed samples. The next stage would pull in new samples from this same tray. If the outgoing tray at a given stage began to fill, then the technicians filling it would slow down their work. In some cases, they would even offer their assistance to the next stage to help them catch up. Shifting to a pull-based operation made backlogs impossible: the pace of the pipeline would adapt to whatever stage was running slowest.
author: Cal Newport

text: find easiest.) Recall, when I say "projects," I mean something substantial enough to require multiple sessions to complete. (Strategies for containing smaller commitments, which we call "tasks," were discussed in the preceding proposition.) When a new project is pushed toward you, place it in the holding-pen section of your list. There is no bound to the size of your holding tank. The active position of the list, by contrast, should be limited to three projects at most. When scheduling your time, you should focus your attention only on the projects on your active list. When you complete one of these projects, you can remove it from your list. This leaves open a free slot that you can fill by pulling in a new project from the holding tank.
author: Cal Newport

text: When adding a new project to your holding tank, it's important to update the source of this new obligation about what they should expect. To do so, send an acknowledgment message that formally acknowledges the project that you're committing to complete, but that also includes the following three pieces of extra information: (1) a request for any additional details you need from the source before you can start the project, (2) a count of the number of existing projects already on your lists, and (3) an estimate of when you expect to complete this new work. After sending this message, label the project with the time estimate you included in your acknowledgment message so you won't later forget. Notice, when making this estimate, you can look at the estimates on all of your existing projects to help inform a realistic prediction.
author: Cal Newport

text: You should update and clean your lists once a week. In addition to pulling in new work to fill empty slots on your active list, you should also review upcoming deadlines. Prioritize what's due soon, and send updates for any work that you know you're not going to finish by the time promised. These cleaning sessions also provide a good opportunity to remove from your holding tank projects that are languishing. If you've delayed the same project again and again, for example, this might be a good sign that you're not really equipped to handle it, or that it falls outside your comfort zone.
author: Cal Newport

In the moment, it might exude a false sense of usefulness, but when continued over time, it estranges us from our fundamental nature, generates misery, and, from a strictly economic perspective, almost certainly holds us back from reaching

text: MAKE A FIVE-YEAR PLAN Most people restrict their long-term planning to cover something like the next few months. You might have a goal, for example, to write and submit an academic paper by the end of the fall, or introduce a new product over the summer. Planning at this scale is certainly necessary, as without it you might end up mired in shallow demands and never really move forward on anything impor tant. I suggest, however, also crafting a plan that covers an even larger scale: what you would like to accomplish in the next five years or so. The specific choice of five years is somewhat arbitrary. You can adjust this quantity to fit the reality of your situation: if you've just started a four-year degree program, for example, a four-year plan might make more sense. The key to this suggestion, however, is that your time horizon should include at least several years.
author: Cal Newport

text: By deploying a blanket policy of doubling these initial esti-mates, you can counter this instinct toward unjustified optimism. The result: plans that can be completed at a more leisurely pace. The fear here, of course, is that by doubling these timelines, you'll drastically reduce what you accomplish. But your original plans were never realistic or sustainable in the first place. A key tenet of slow productivity is that grand achievement is built on the steady accumulation of modest results over time. This path is long. Pace yourself.
author: Cal Newport

text: We arrive, finally, at the smallest timescale relevant to our discussion of taking longer: the individual day. One of the central joys of slowing down your work pace is that it frees you from needing to attack every day with frantic intensity. To reap this benefit, how-ever, you actually have to simplify your daily schedule. Toning down your seasonal and long-term plans won't help if you persist in filling every hour of the current day with more work than you can hope to complete. All three timescales must be tamed together. To create more reasonable workdays, I have two suggestions: first, reduce the number of tasks you schedule, and second, reduce the number of appointments on your calendar. In other words, cut back on what you plan to accomplish while increasing your available time.
author: Cal Newport

text: tactic here is to take on a highly visible but low-impact project during this season that you can use to temporarily deflect new work that comes your way: "I'm happy to lead that internal review proj-ect, but I'm really focused this month on mastering this new marketing software, so let's wait until the New Year to get started." The key is to choose a deflection project that itself doesn't require a lot of collaboration, meetings, or urgent messages. Solo writing or research projects work well here.
author: Cal Newport

text: Schedule Rest Projects It can be stressful to start blocking out large chunks of time on your calendar for a major new project. Each new appointment you add represents less flexibility and more intense work in your near-future schedule. As your calendar continues to fill during busy periods, a sense of mild despair can arise. How will I ever get this all done? A clever way to balance this stress is to pair each major work project with a corresponding rest project. The idea is simple: after putting aside time on your calendar for a major work project, schedule in the days or weeks immediately following it time to pursue something leisurely and unrelated to your work.
author: Cal Newport

text: Work in Cycles The software development company Basecamp is known for experimenting with innovative management practices. This is perhaps not surprising given that its cofounder and current CEO, Jason Fried, once published a book titled It Doesn't Have to Be Crazy at Work. One of Basecamp's more striking policies is the consolidation of work into "cycles." Each cycle lasts from six to eight weeks. During those weeks, teams focus on clear and urgent goals. Crucially, each cycle is then followed by a two-week "cooldown" small issues and deciding what to tackle next. "It's sometimes tempting to simply extend the cycles into the cooldown period to fit in more work," explains the Basecamp employee handbook. "But the goal is to resist this temptation."
author: Cal Newport

text: These forces affect our professional efforts. Oliver's forest strolls weren't just about finding quiet. This outdoor context pulled on rich threads from her past, resulting in a perception of work that was more alive, varied, and natural in its pace than if she had spent those exact same hours writing at a perfectly nice home office desk. This proposition asks you to similarly assess the context of your most important work through this poetic lens. By taking care in your choice of physical spaces and rituals, you can not only transform the experience of your efforts into something more interesting and sustainable, but more fully tap into your latent bril-liance.
author: Cal Newport

text: This is why Benchley retreated to the furnace factory and McCullough to his garden shed. They sought a more advantageous mental space to produce meaningful work. By calming their relational memory system, they could slow their perception of time and allow their attention to mold itself more completely around a singular pursuit. What's more important about these observations is that the aesthetics of their outside-the-home workspaces didn't really matter...What counted was their disconnection from the familiar. A citadel to creative concentration need not be a literal place. It just needs to be free of laundry baskets.
author: Cal Newport

text: My advice here has two parts. First, form your own personalized rituals around the work you find most important. Second, in doing so, ensure your rituals are sufficiently striking to effectively shift your mental state into something more supportive of your goals. The second principle of productivity asks that you work at a more natural pace. It's suitable that this suggestion about rituals closes this chapter, as there are few strategies that will more effectively transform your perception of time, pushing your experience away from anxiety and toward the more sublimely natural than to add a dash of poetic mystery to your efforts.
author: Cal Newport

text: Obsess over the quality of what you produce, even if this means missing opportunities in the short term. Leverage the value of these results to gain more and more freedom in your efforts over the long term.
author: Cal Newport

text: There's a reason why this principle is presented last: it's the glue that holds the practice of slow productivity together. Doing fewer things and working at a natural pace are both absolutely necessary components of this philosophy, but if those earlier principles are implemented on their own, without an accompanying obsession with quality, they might serve only to fray your relationship to work over time-casting your professional efforts as an imposition that you must tame. It's in the obsession over what you're producing that slowness can transcend its role as just one more strategy on the arid battlegrounds of work-life wars and become a necessary imperative—an engine that drives a meaningful professional life.
author: Cal Newport

text: The third and final principle of slow productivity asks that you obsess over the quality of the core activities in your professional life. The goal here is not about becoming really good for the sake of being really good at your job (though this is nice). As I'll argue next, you should be focused on the quality of what you produce because quality turns out to be connected in unexpected ways to our desire to escape pseudo-productivity and embrace something slower.
author: Cal Newport

text: Without a firm rooting in creation, religion is always drifting off into some kind of pious sentimentalism or sophisticated intellectualism.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: "I would rather. I think, undergo the famous dark night of the soul than encountink, church the dread hootenanny, but these purely personal preferences are of no account, and maladaptive to boot." [Annie Dillard]
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I have no patience with and will not knowingly give comfort to obscurantist or anti-intellectual tendencies in the church.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: This is my essential educational task: to develop and draw out into articulateness this personal word, to teach people to pray.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Real work always includes a respect for the material at hand. The material can be a pork loin, or a mahogany plank, or a lump of clay, or the will of God, but when the work is done well there is a kind of submission of will to the conditions at hand, a cultivation of humility. It is a noticeable feature in all skilled workers - woodworkers, potters, poets, and prayers. I learned it in the butcher shop.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Nothing we do by the exercise of our wills will ever come close to approximating what is done to us by other wills.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: But there are different ways of being passive: there is an indolent, inattentive passivity that approximates the existence of a slug; and there is a willed and attentive passivity that is something more like worship.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Pastoral work, I learned later, is that aspect of Christian ministry that specializes in the ordinary.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Most people, most of the time, are not in crisis.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Most of us, most of the time, are engaged in simple, routine tasks, and small talk is the natural language.If pastors belittle it, we belittle what most people are doing most of the time, and the gospel is misrepresented.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Some insights are only accessible while laughing. Others arrive only by indirection.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: On the other hand, if the pastor rigorously defines people as fellow sinners, he or she will be prepared to share grief, shortcomings, pain, failure, and have plenty of time left over to watch for the signs of God's grace operating in this wilderness, and then fill the air with praises for what he discovers.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: The happy result of a theological understanding of people as sinners is that the pastor is saved from continual surprise that they are in fact sinners.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: It is more likely, though, a new disguise for an old sin — the ancient business of making idols. God calls people to himself, but they turn away to something less than God, fashioning a religious experience but avoiding God.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: A quick theological eye that is able to pick up the movements of sin hiding behind these seemingly innocent characteristics will keep a pastor on track, doing what he or she was called to do: sharing a ministry of grace and forgiveness centered in Jesus Christ.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I reflect on that incident occasionally. Am I keeping the line clear between what I am committed to and what people are asking of me? Is my primary orientation God's grace, his mercy, his action in Creation and covenant? And am I committed to it enough that when people ask me to do something that will not lead them into a more mature participation in these realities, I refuse?
author: Eugene Peterson

text: The idea for a sabbatical developed from a two-pronged stimulus: fatigue and frustration. I was tired. That's hardly unusual in itself, but it was a tiredness that vacations weren't fixing — a tiredness of spirit, an inner boredom. I sensed spiritual core to my fatigue and was looking for a spiritual remedy.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I have been feeling the need for just such a time of restoration for about two years. The sense that my reserves are low, that my margins of creativity are crowded, becomes more acute each week. I feel the need for some 'desert time — for silence, for solitude, for prayer.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: One of the dangers of a long-term pastorate. is the development of neurotic dependencies between pastor and people.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: “Cheap grace is the grace we bestow on ourselves. Cheap grace is the preaching of forgiveness without requiring repentance, baptism without church discipline, Communion without confession.... Cheap grace is grace without discipleship, grace without the cross, grace without Jesus Christ, living and incarnate.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer, _The Cost Of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “When Christ calls a man, he bids him come and die.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer, The Cost of Discipleship
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Costly grace is the gospel which must be sought again and again and again, the gift which must be asked for, the door at which a man must knock. Such grace is costly because it calls us to follow, and it is grace because it calls us to follow Jesus Christ. It is costly because it costs a man his life, and it is grace because it gives a man the only true life. It is costly because it condemns sin, and grace because it justifies the sinner. Above all, it is costly because it cost God the life of his Son: 'Ye were bought at a price', and what has cost God much cannot be cheap for us. Above all, it is grace because God did not reckon his Son too dear a price to pay for our life, but delivered him up for us. Costly grace is the Incarnation of God.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Earthly goods are given to be used, not to be collected. In the wilderness God gave Israel the manna every day, and they had no need to worry about food and drink. Indeed, if they kept any of the manna over until the next day, it went bad. In the same way, the disciple must receive his portion from God every day. If he stores it up as a permanent possession, he spoils not only the gift, but himself as well, for he sets his heart on accumulated wealth, and makes it a barrier between himself and God. Where our treasure is, there is our trust, our security, our consolation and our God. Hoarding is idolatry.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “The messengers of Jesus will be hated to the end of time. They will be blamed for all the division which rend cities and homes. Jesus and his disciples will be condemned on all sides for undermining family life, and for leading the nation astray; they will be called crazy fanatics and disturbers of the peace. The disciples will be sorely tempted to desert their Lord. But the end is also near, and they must hold on and persevere until it comes. Only he will be blessed who remains loyal to Jesus and his word until the end.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “The community of the saints is not an "ideal" community consisting of perfect and sinless men and women, where there is no need of further repentance. No, it is a community which proves that it is worthy of the gospel of forgiveness by constantly and sincerely proclaiming _God's_ forgiveness...Sanctification means driving out the world from the Church as well as separating the Church from the world. But the purpose of such discipline is not to establish a community of the perfect, but a community consisting of men who really live under the forgiving mercy of God.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “The earthly form of Christ is the form that died on the cross. The image of God is the image of Christ crucified. It is to this image that the life of the disciples must be conformed; in other words, they must be conformed to his death (Phil 3.10, Rom 6.4) The Christian life is a life of crucifixion (Gal 2.19) In baptism the form of Christ's death is impressed upon his own. They are dead to the flesh and to sin, they are dead to the world, and the world is dead to them (Gal 6.14). Anybody living in the strength of Christ's baptism lives in the strength of Christ's death.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “If any man would come after me, let him deny himself." The disciple must say to himself the same words Peter said of Christ when he denied him: "I know not this man." Self-denial is never just a series of isolated acts of mortification or asceticism. It is not suicide, for there is an element of self-will even in that. To deny oneself is to be aware only of Christ and no more of self, to see only him who goes before and no more the road which is too hard for us. Once more, all that self denial can say is: "He leads the way, keep close to him.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Let the Christian remain in the world, not because of the good gifts of creation, nor because of his responsibility for the course of the world, but for the sake of the Church. Let him remain in the world to engage in frontal assault on it, and let him live the life of his secular calling in order to show himself as a stranger in the world all the more. But that is only possible if we are visible members of the Church. The antithesis between the world and the Church must be borne out in the world. That was the purpose of the incarnation. That is why Christ died among his enemies. That is the reason and the only reason why the slave must remain a slave and the Christian remain subject to the powers that be.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “True prayer is done in secret, but this does not rule out the fellowship of prayer altogether, however clearly we may be aware of its dangers. In the last resort it is immaterial whether we pray in the open street or in the secrecy of our chambers, whether briefly or lenghtily, in the Litany of the Church, or with the sigh of one who knows not what he should pray for. True prayer does not depend either on the individual or the whole body of the faithful, but solely upon the knowledge that our Heavenly Father knows our needs.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled.' Not only do the followers of Jesus renounce their rights, they renounce their own righteousness too. They get no praise for their achievements or sacrifices. They cannot have righteousness except by hungering and thirsting for it (this applies equally to their own righteousness and to the righteousness of God on Earth), always they look forward to the future righteousness of God, but they cannot establish it for themselves. Those who follow Jesus grow hungry and thirsty on the way.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy.' These men without possessions or power, these strangers on Earth, these sinners, these followers of Jesus, have in their life with him renounced their own dignity, for they are merciful. As if their own needs and their own distress were not enough, they take upon themselves the distress and humiliation of others. They have an irresistible love for the down-trodden, the sick, the wretched, the wronged, the outcast and all who are tortured with anxiety. They go out and seek all who are enmeshed in the toils of sin and guilt. No distress is too great, no sin too appalling for their pity. If any man falls into disgrace, the merciful will sacrifice their own honour to shield him, and take his shame upon themselves.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “The new situation must be created, in which it is possible to believe on Jesus as God incarnate; that is the impossible situation in which everything is staked solely on the word of Jesus. Peter had to leave the ship and risk his life on the sea, in order to learn both his own weakness and the almighty power of his Lord. If Peter had not taken the risk, he would never have learnt the meaning of faith. Before he can believe, the utterly impossible and ethically irresponsible situation on the waves of the sea must be displayed. The road to faith passes through obedience to the call of Jesus. Unless a definite step is demanded, the call vanishes into thin air, and if men imagine that they can follow Jesus without taking this step, they are deluding themselves like fanatics.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “But the disciple had the advantage over the Pharisee in that his doing of the law is in fact perfect. How is such a thing possible? Because between the disciples and the law stands one who has perfectly fulfilled it, on with whom they live in communion...Jesus not only possesses this righteousness, but is himself the personal embodiment of it. He _is_ the righteousness of the disciples...This is where the righteousness of the disciple exceeds that of the Pharisees; it is grounded solely upon the call to fellowship with him who alone fulfills the law.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “No one should be surprised at the difficulty of faith, if there is some part of his life where he is consciously resisting or disobeying the commandment of Jesus. Is there some part of your life which you are refusing to surrender at his behest, some sinful passion, maybe, or some animosity, some hope, perhaps your ambition or your reason? ... How can you hope to enter into communion with him when at some point in your life you are running away from him?” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Take courage and confess your sin, says Luther, do not try to run away from it, but believe more boldly still. You are a sinner, so be a sinner, and don't try to become what you are not. Yes, and become a sinner again and again every day, and be bold about it. But to whom can such words be addressed, except to those who from the bottom of their hearts make a daily renunciation of sin and of every barrier which hinders them from following Christ, but who nevertheless are troubled by their daily faithlessness and sin? Who can hear these words without endangering his faith but he who hears their consolation as a renewed summons to follow Christ?” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “He stands between us and God, and for that very reason he stands between us and all other men and things. _He is the Mediator_, not only between God and man, but between man and man, between man and reality. Since the whole world was created through him and unto him (John 1.3; I Cor. 8.6; Heb. 1.2), he is the sole Mediator in the world. Since his coming man has no immediate relationship of his own any more to anything, neither to God nor to the world; Christ wants to be the mediator. Of course, there are plenty of gods who offer men direct access, and the world naturally uses every means in its power to retain its direct hold on men, but that is the very reason why it is so bitterly opposed to Christ, the Mediator.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Justification is the means whereby we appropriate the saving act of God in the past, and sanctification the promise of God's activity in the present and future...Justification is primarily concerned with the relation between man and the law of God, sanctification with the Christian's separation from the world until the second coming of Christ...Justification is the new creation of the new man, and sanctification is his preservation until the day of Jesus Christ.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “At the end of a life spent in the pursuit of knowledge Faust has to confess: "I now see that we can nothing know." That is the answer to a sum, it is the outcome of a long experience. But as Kierkegaard observed, it is quite a different thing when a freshman comes up to the university and uses the same sentiment to justify his indolence. As the answer to a sum it is perfectly true, but as the initial data it is a piece of self-deception. For acquired knowledge cannot be divorced from the existence in which it is acquired. The only man who has the right to say that he is justified by grace alone is the man who has left all to follow Christ. Such a man knows that the call to discipleship is a gift of grace, and that the call is inseparable from the grace. But those who try to use this grace as a dispensation from following Christ are simply deceiving themselves.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “The truth is that so long as we hold both sides of the proposition together they contain nothing inconsistent with right belief, but as soon as one is divorced from the other, it is bound to prove a stumbling block. "Only those who believe obey" is what we say to that part of a believer's soul which obeys, and "only those who obey believe" is what we say to that part of the soul of the obedient which believes. If the first half of the proposition stands alone, the believer is exposed to the danger of cheap grace, which is another word for damnation. If the second half stands alone, the believer is exposed to the danger of salvation through works, which is also another word for damnation.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “Therefore let every soul be in subjection to the higher powers' (Rom 13.1). The Christian must not be drawn to the bearers of high office; his calling is to stay below. The higher power are over him, and he must remain under them. The world exercises dominion, the Christian serves, and thus he shares the earthly lot of his Lord, who became a servant. 'For there is no power but of God.' (Mark 10.42-45) These words are addressed to the Christians, not to the powers.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “When He was challenged by Jesus to accept a life of voluntary poverty, the rich young man knew he was faced with the simple alternative of obedience or disobedience. When Levi was called from the receipt of custom and Peter from his nets, there was no doubt that Jesus meant business. Both of them were to leave everything and follow. Again, when Peter was called to walk on the rolling sea, he had to get up and risk his life. Only one thing was required in each case-to rely on Christ's word, and cling to it as offering greater security than all the securities in the world.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “There is always a danger that in our asceticism we shall be tempted to imitate the sufferings of Christ. This is a pious but godless ambition, for beneath it there always lurks the notion that it is possible for us to step into Christ's shoes and suffer as he did and kill the old Adam. We are then presuming to undertake that bitter work of eternal redemption which Christ himself wrought for us. The motive of asceticism was more limited--to equip us for better service and deeper humiliation.” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: “It is hardly surprising that the harbinger of God's love has been accused of hatred of the human race. Who has a right to speak thus of love for father and mother, for son and daughter, but the destroyer of all human life on the one hand, or the Creator of a new life on the other? Who dare lay such an exclusive claim to man's love and devotion, but the enemy of mankind on the one hand, and the Saviour of mankind on the other? Who but the devil, or Christ, the Prince of Peace, willy carry the sword into men's houses?” ― Dietrich Bonhoeffer , _The Cost of Discipleship_
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

text: Now, the present war has taught us to be cautious with our prophecies. For not only did it shatter all our expectations regarding the civilizing influence of culture and the peaceful disposition of nations, but it also cruelly disappointed all our thoughts and predictions in its duration and course, in its development and expansion. We act wisely, therefore, if we adopt a reserved and somewhat skeptical attitude towards the characterizations of the new period that will dawn with peace. But that does not take away from the fact that there are some solid data on which we can certainly rely, and which guide our thinking and acting in a specific direction.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Take, for example, these irrefutable facts! Ten million men have already been wounded or killed on the battlefields, and this number may well be increased by half, if not doubled, before the end of the war. The war costs of the belligerent nations have already risen to two hundred billion guilders and have by no means reached their peak. The crisis expenditures in neutral countries have risen proportionally, and in our country, for example, are already approaching one billion guilders. The military service of men has forced thousands and hundreds of thousands of women to take their place in all sorts of labor; and all the men who will return from the war or from mobilization must be reintegrated into society and helped to find work.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. the articles in De Standaard of 23 Feb. 1917 and seq. on: When it is peace, and: New Orientation necessary (by Mr. H. Colijn).
author: Herman Bavinck

text: However, there are special reasons why this expectation may be cherished. Education and upbringing have suffered considerable damage in this war. Officially, education continues and schools remain open. But everyone understands that in reality, this is often a very sad state of affairs. Teachers, lecturers, and professors in the warring countries have been called up for service by the thousands and a considerable number have been killed or wounded. The pupils of the primary school were therefore, in numbers of seventy and more, grouped together in one class and entrusted to a single teacher, who can do little with such a large class and often cannot even maintain order in it. There is also a great lack of supervision and control by competent persons, because they too have for the most part been called up for service to the fatherland. ¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ The situation in the Churches is just as sad as in the schools. Recently, the press reported from France that, because thousands of priests are incorporated into the army as chaplains, nurses, or also as ordinary soldiers, half of the rural parishes are deprived of their pastors; many an old priest has to serve five or more parishes, so that religious services, administration of the mass and last rites, confession and communion, religious instruction, and Sunday observance are severely lacking. De Heraut, April 8, 1917, in the section: Buitenland (Abroad).
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Whoever compares this entire Entente policy with that of Prussian militarism and the pan-Germanic annexationists comes to the conclusion that the peoples have little to reproach each other for.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: But perhaps all this will not happen so quickly after the war. One cannot count on the sympathies of princes and peoples, on agreements and treaties of the powers, on eternal edicts of countries and states. But Germany cannot be blamed for not relying on these favorable possibilities and for imagining the future to be difficult and serious. People there live in the awareness that the world, which has become alienated from Germany, must be won again. And they feel that this can only be done by working so hard, and by exerting all their forces to such an extent, that the products of their labor surpass those of all other peoples in quality and quantity. And education and upbringing must also be made subservient to this gigantic task of the future.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: But now that this human has appeared on the scene, especially as the cultured man of the twentieth century, equipped with an unprecedented knowledge of and dominion over nature, the unconscious evolution is increasingly handing over the leadership of the process to this knowing and goal-setting human. For he is, through his intellect and will, capable of intervening in the developmental course of things and guiding it into new paths. Blind nature, in its drive, was the creator of man and became seeing in him; and that man now, in turn, knowingly and willingly, becomes the creator of society and the state, of science and art, and of the whole of culture; he has become his own lord and master, with no sovereign above him, the smith of his own fortune, providence itself on earth. For knowledge is power, to know is to foresee, to labor is to create, and to create is divine.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: All these ideas are not new, not even in their application to teaching and education. But they are nevertheless pushed forward forcefully by the war and are developed into a theoretical and practical system. The most salutary consequences are expected from its application in the approaching period of peace; the optimism that sustains all education in America is spreading to Europe and inspiring it with new hope. In a recent lecture in Leeds, Mr. M. E. Sadler gave a clear overview of the educational ideas that prevail in the United States of America and make the entire school system there subservient to the needs of society. It is recognized in this country, he said, that a competent and inspiring education is a great power for the promotion of industrial development and for the cultivation of a spirit of good citizenship.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: All this resulted in idealism, even in Germany, changing and increasingly assuming a pragmatist (activist) and utilitarian character. Through intellect, man had risen above the animal, had become a "tool-making animal," and had learned to subject nature to himself. Thinking, which was born from life in the struggle for existence, also has its goal in that life; it is not a Selbstzweck (end in itself), but is useful and orders reality so that it promotes the well-being of man; representations, concepts, ideas are tools we use to master the world; truth and value are determined by biology. Accordingly, science, as is now said in leading circles, is no longer concerned with knowing an unknowable, metaphysical truth; but, just as it has emerged from life with all culture, so it is also subservient to life, and to be valued as one of the many weapons with which man has equipped himself in the struggle for existence.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ The late Theodor Lipps said: "The sciences have no reason to be ashamed of their utility; whatever the value of science as such may be, in any case it gains higher value when it also serves life. Indeed, all science should ultimately serve life, i.e., the whole man and the whole of humanity." (in W. Stern, Die Jugendkunde als Kulturforderung. Leipzig, Quelle u. Meyer 1916, p. 64). ² On Mach († 19 Feb. 1916), one can consult, among others: Dr. Bernhard Hell, Ernst Machs Philosophie. Stuttgart 1907. Höffding, Moderne Philosophen. Leipzig, Reisland 1905. Kleinpeter, Die Erkenntnistheorie der Naturforscher der Gegenwart. Leipzig, Barth 1905. Enklaar, "Ernst Mach," Tijdspiegel, July 1917, pp. 203-238.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: In the direction that education should now take, according to many, this practical striving comes to light very clearly. Hitherto, the aim of education was to be defined in a general formula, which applied to all people and for all times. Whether this aim was set in the development of the intellect, in the ennobling of the heart, or in the strengthening of the will, in the formation of the personality or in the harmonious unfolding of all its faculties and powers, one always dealt with an ideal to which general validity was ascribed. But this view is now contested on various grounds.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Firstly, it is argued that such an absolute educational ideal does not exist. In the 17th and 18th centuries, people still believed in an infallible pedagogical dogma, and even Herbart was still of the opinion that such a general ideal for education could be derived from ethics; but the criticism leveled against this philosophical or religious theory by the individualism of Schopenhauer, Feuerbach, Nietzsche, and others has, it is believed, conclusively demonstrated its untenability. There is no objective, unchanging pedagogical ideal. The science of education is not an independent science developing according to its own idea and law, but it is in the closest connection with the culture of its time, follows the movement that it takes, and receives its ideal from the society in which it is rooted.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Secondly, such a general educational ideal takes far too little or even no account of the great diversity that exists among children; it can therefore, by its very nature, be nothing but vague and unclear, and does not fit the children either. What, for example, is one to do with the ideal of a harmonious development of all gifts and powers, if one seriously takes into account the hundreds of children in a primary school, who will enter practical life at about 13 or 14 years of age? With by far the most of them, one cannot and need not go further than making them useful members of society, and having them acquire the skills and abilities necessary for the exercise of their daily profession. "Kulturbildung" (cultural education) is therefore a grand word and an unattainable ideal; the educator who is content with "Berufsbildung" (vocational training) acts much more wisely and practically.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Thirdly, it deserves consideration that pedagogy, which wants to start from general principles, creates hopeless disagreement and confusion; for everyone holds their own belief or conviction, their own worldview and philosophy of life. On the other hand, there is a chance that when all place themselves on the ground of reality, they will meet each other time and again, and in many cases can cooperate to improve society and to increase the sum of happiness for humanity. ¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. e.g. Walter Oehme, "Strömungen der modernen Pädagogik," Sozialistische Monatshefte 1914, 10th issue, pp. 622-630. W. Peters, Einführung in die Pädagogik auf psychologischer Grundlage. Leipzig, Quelle und Meyer 1916, pp. 1-2.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Slotemaker de Bruine, Christendom en Maatschappij 1917, p. 171 ff. ³ Fabius, Studiën en Schetsen, Oct. 1916, pp. 165, 166.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: A similar view can now easily be extended from property to the family, to parents and children. Procreation is also actually a social function, which the community has to regulate and guide. The possession of children is not for the convenience or benefit of the parents, but serves to promote the interest of the community. Parents cannot therefore do with their children as they wish, but are accountable and responsible to society for whether and how they raise them. If they are incapable or unwilling for this task, the state has the right to relieve them of parental authority or to remove them from it, and to take the children under its protection against them. More and more, the state thereby infringes on the freedom of the individual, on the rights of the family, on the authority and power of the parents.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Along this line of thought, it is increasingly emphasized that education may no longer remain a private affair of parents and teachers, but must increasingly become a matter for the entire nation and the organized society. For education concerns the highest interest of the state, the independence, prosperity, and flourishing of the people as a whole, its physical and spiritual health, its self-preservation and self-development in the future. All citizens must therefore be informed of the needs and demands of the time; and all must, in their own way, cooperate in the grand task of uplifting the people and making them meet these demands.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Stern, Die Jugendkunde als Kulturforderung. Leipzig 1916, p. 3.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Indeed, in the last century, not only has our knowledge and ability expanded immensely, but so has the endeavor to let an ever-widening circle of the population share in this development. Whereas in former times civilization was only the part of a privileged class, now in all circles of the people the need has awakened to also enjoy the goods of culture. With the content of our knowledge, the number of those who wish to profit from it has also increased. And this, as Tews remarks, is not to be considered a curse, but a blessing, for otherwise the distance between the higher and lower classes of society would become ever greater, ¹ and the gap between the artes liberales and the artes mechanicae, between intellectual and manual labor, ever deeper. If one wishes, one can say with this author that a social pedagogy has thus been born, which, however, does not form a contrast with individual pedagogy, but only extends education to all.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ J. Tews, Socialpädagogische Reformen. Langensalza 1900, pp. 3-5. Pädagogisches Magazin 140.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: This socialization of education is further promoted by the fact that it is increasingly assuming an exact scientific character, and thus goes beyond the powers of the family. Modern family life, it is said, suffers and languishes under all sorts of pressure; it is, according to many, generally a "failure"; for that reason alone, it is better for children to receive their education in proper institutions and from competent pedagogues, than from stupid and bad parents. Modern schools already, fortunately, take much work off the hands of parents; but that would be even more the case with a still more rational and especially systematic organization of education, which would extend over the entire nation and make subjects like sociology, art history, music, and dance main subjects; at the same time, woman would then be delivered from her family slavery and soon also from her economic slavery. ²
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Thus N. van Suchtelen, De stille lach, 1916, p. 67.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Also, measures that have already been taken here and there, such as premiums and privileges for a numerous offspring, supplements to salaries for large families, heavier taxation of unmarried people, etc., seem to have little power to turn the tide of neo-Malthusianism. Money does not compensate for the burden and trouble associated with maintaining and caring for a family. Leroy-Beaulieu, the French sociologist, rightly attributed the main cause of this evil in 1910 to the weakening of religious belief, and stated in 1913 that the only means to save the French people from ruin lay in a return to faith and to an ideal, self-sacrificing disposition.¹ As long as no other religious and moral principles prevail than those that flow from a mechanistic-evolutionary worldview, no conversion and no return to better morals can be expected. The courage to build and maintain a family blossoms from the root of faith.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ In Mausbach, Ehe und Kindersegen. M. Gladbach 1917, p. 10.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: However, when it comes to offspring, it is not only about quantity, but also about quality. Every year, in all countries, a large number of unfortunate, sickly, defective, hereditarily burdened children are born, who remain a burden to society their whole lives, cost it an immense amount of money and effort, and in return can provide it with no service at all. This sad state of affairs has in recent years often raised the question of whether there is a means to prevent the birth of such unfortunate children, and to promote that of healthy and strong children in body and mind. And it seemed that the theory of evolution again pointed a way to salvation.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Dr. Rijk Kramer, "Een wetenschappelijke puzzle," Orgaan van de Christ. Vereeniging van Nat. en Geneesk. in Nederland, 1906/7, issue 4, pp. 190-202. ² In this country, especially with Dr. J. text: Around 1860, Mendel began to investigate the inheritance of color in peas, at the same time that Darwin was working on his Origin of Species. He discovered that there are two types of organisms: purebred (racially pure) and hybrids or bastards. The former are seed-stable and produce a uniform offspring, but the latter produce a polymorphic offspring. Every higher living being arises from the fusion of two reproductive cells, and as soon as these two differ even slightly in their hereditary composition, the growing being is in a sense a bastard and will form differently constituted reproductive cells. This explains the enormous polymorphism of nature.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: An analogy of these changes occurring through hybridization can already be found in chemistry, where the combination of different substances can produce entirely new, constant substances (e.g., water from a combination of hydrogen and oxygen). But much better examples are provided by plant and flower nurseries and by the breeding of horses, cattle, sheep, goats, etc. If we now transfer this to human beings, the assumption is obvious that if a man and a woman differ in a number of characteristics, e.g., hair color, nose shape, body length, etc., their offspring, due to the possibility of all sorts of combinations, will show an incalculably large number of different forms. And so the question arose whether the care for such combinations could not also be made subservient to the improvement of the human race, just as with plants and animals.
author: Herman Bavinck

author: Herman Bavinck

text: Race improvement, mother and infant protection may be of high importance for education; yet, education itself is concerned with the physical and mental formation of the child and is entrusted with its own, significant task. In order for it to fulfill this properly, in accordance with the demands of the time, contemporary pedagogues strive to free it from theoretical considerations and to base it on scientifically exact, that is, on empirical data. Empirical psychology and pedagogy must be the foundation of the new education.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ On the history of psychology, see O. Klemm, Geschichte der Psychologie, Teubner 1911. Cf. further N. Ach, Über den Willensakt und das Temperament. Eine experimentelle Untersuchung, Leipzig, Quelle und Meyer 1910. L. Bouman, Psychische Aktiviteit, 1916. Roels, De psychologie van den wil. Nijmegen, Malmberg 1916.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Psychology simply has a essentially different object than natural science, and can therefore never become pure physics. Sensation, perception, thinking, consciousness, feeling, will, free will, etc. are phenomena that do not exist spatially and therefore cannot be calculated quantitatively. Experience here ultimately always comes down to self-observation. To that, as Möbius rightly says, all natural scientific endeavors change nothing, for indirect observations, measurements, experiments do give information about the "how much," but not about the "what."¹ And to all these objections is then added at the end the ethical consideration, whether it is permissible and thus also possible, to artificially arouse religious and ethical feelings or actions in the soul life, which precisely through this artificiality would lose their own character.²
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Möbius, Die Hoffnungslosigkeit aller Psychologie, Halle, Marhold 1907, p. 13. ² Cf. Münsterberg, Grundzüge der Psychotechnik, Leipzig 1914, pp. 106-128. Gutberlet, Experimentelle Psychologie mit besonderer Berücksichtigung der Pädagogik, Paderborn 1915. Braunshausen, Einführung in die experimentelle Psychologie, Leipzig, Teubner 1915. Ruttmann, Hauptergebnisse der Psychologie, Leipzig, Wunderlich 1914. Art. in Roloff's Lexikon der Pädagogik I 1194 ff. Wunderle, Experimentelle Pädagogik, Eichstätt 1914. Bouman, "Experimenteele Psychologie," Handelingen van het Nationaal Christelijk Schoolcongres, Oct. 1913, Kampen, J. H. Kok, pp. 38 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: The new education, however, bases its hope for the future not so much on empirical psychology in general, but specifically on the psychology of the child. When empirical psychology entered the field of science and chose concrete psychic reality as the object of its investigation, it embarked on a path that had a beginning but no end. The so-called differential psychology can be endlessly specialized. Even if we leave aside plant and animal psychology, which have enjoyed great interest in recent years, the diversity in the psychic life of humans remains so endlessly vast that the research directed towards it knows no bounds. There are, of course, properties, both physical and mental, that are inherent to humans as such and are therefore found in all people, so that the right of general psychology cannot be disputed. But within that unity, what an immeasurably rich diversity!
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Once one has focused on this and set its knowledge as a goal, the field of investigation expands in all directions. Empirical psychology can then study men and women, races and peoples, city dwellers and country folk; normal and abnormal individuals, such as criminals and the insane; special groups like geniuses, scholars, artists, generals, preachers, teachers, farmers, laborers, etc.; and also adults, men and—not to mention more—the elderly, and children in their early and later years. And the study of the latter is, of course, of particular importance for pedagogy.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: In the beginning, this young science devoted its attention primarily to the child before school age, from birth to the third or sixth year of life. And it then tried, through careful observation and in great detail, to trace the development, both physical and mental, of the child in all its faculties and powers during these years. Thus it described how the child at birth was not at a zero point, but already possessed some impressions and movements, and how from there it gradually, through "learning," practice, imitation, play, acquired various skills and abilities, such as sitting upright, standing, crawling, walking, grasping, etc.; and likewise perceiving and noticing, recognizing and remembering, thinking and speaking, etc. The development of its faults and defects, especially lying, was not forgotten, any more than that of its religious, moral, and aesthetic feelings.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ W. Preyer, Die Seele des Kindes 8th ed. Leipzig, Grieben 1912. Karl Groos, Das Seelenleben des Kindes 3rd ed. Berlin, Reuther und Reichard 1911. A. Myroff, Ueber das Seelenleben des Kindes 2nd ed. Berlin, Hanstein 1911. W. Stern, Psychologie der frühen Kindheit. Leipzig, Quelle und Meyer 1914. Meumann, Experimentelle Pädagogik, first part.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: But this method gains much more significance when the research extends to children of school age.¹ While it is true that attention has been paid to the results of education in the past, and men like Pestalozzi, Froebel, and others have sought to improve teaching methods, the study of the schoolchild has only been systematically and purposefully undertaken in recent years. The aim is to make psychological research on the child in school subservient to teaching and education and to judge, based on empirical data, which is the best path to follow. Anyone who reflects for a moment on this new science realizes that an extraordinarily extensive field of research opens up here. The entire relationship of the child, physically and mentally, in all its gifts and powers, to the school, to the teachers, to the curriculum with all its subjects, to its fellow pupils and environment, is thereby brought to the fore.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ For the psychology of adolescence, see my: De opvoeding der rijpere jeugd (The Education of the Adolescent), Kampen, J. H. Kok 1916, p. 132 ff. and the literature cited there.

text: In particular, the question of the practical application of psychology was raised in America by the professor at Harvard University, Hugo Münsterberg. In his opinion, psychology increasingly reveals the life of the soul to us as a purely mechanical mechanism, just as natural science has come to the same insight regarding the physical world; but Münsterberg tries to incorporate both mechanisms, the physical and the psychical, into an idealistic, teleological worldview, so that in this case pedagogy determines the goal of education, but, to achieve this goal, makes use of the psychic mechanism as psychology reveals it to us. When psychology is thus placed in the service of a practical goal, it receives from Münsterberg the name of psychotechnics.²
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Münsterberg was born in Germany in 1864, but went to America in 1892, where he became a professor at Harvard University in Cambridge near Boston. In 1910/11, as an exchange professor, he gave lectures on applied psychology in Berlin. In 1913, his Psychologie und Wirtschaftsleben appeared; in 1914, his Grundzüge der Psychotechnik, published by Barth in Leipzig; on Dec. 17, 1916, he died suddenly of a stroke, at the age of 53. Applied psychology is now widely practiced. In Germany, there are already two journals for it: Zeitschrift für angewandte Psychologie by Stern and Lipmann, and Fortschritte der Psychologie und ihrer Anwendungen by Marbe. Cf. Gutberlet, "Die experimentelle Psychologie im Dienste des Lebens," in the Philosophisches Jahrbuch der Görres-Gesellschaft. Fulda 1917, Heft 2, pp. 151-171.
author: Herman Bavinck

Bird, was that girls especially value kindness in a teacher, while boys value honesty! ¹ Meumann, op. cit. I² 47 ff.

author: Herman Bavinck

text: It should also be pointed out that empirical (experimental) pedagogy is not the whole of pedagogy and can never be. Whatever important services it may render, it cannot answer all the questions that arise in education, because not all of them are susceptible to empirical and even less to experimental investigation. Thus, for example, it is impossible according to this method to determine the goal of education, as Münsterberg, Meumann, and others fully acknowledge, and thereby leave room for a religious or philosophical, in any case systematic and normative pedagogy.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ In Gutberlet, Experimentelle Psychologie mit besonderer Rücksicht der Pädagogik, Paderborn 1915, p. 223 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ To cite, by way of example, something from the overwhelmingly rich literature, one might mention: Van Wayenburg, "De geestelijke vermoeidheid," in: Moderne Kinderstudie, Zutphen 1913, pp. 3-43.
