Psychologie usw. Paderborn 1915. Id., "Die experimentelle Psychologie im Dienste des Lebens," Philosophisches Jahrbuch 1917, Heft 2, pp. 131-171. Erismann, Angewandte Psychologie, Berlin, Goeschen 1916. W. A. Lay, Experimentelle Pädagogik, Leipzig 1908 (Aus Natur u. Geisteswelt). Claparède, Psychologie de l'enfant 4th ed., Genève 1911. Binet, Les idées modernes sur les enfants 2nd ed., Paris 1911.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: As mentioned, a somewhat complete description of the more or less certain results of empirical pedagogy would detain us far too long and lead us away from our purpose. But we should pause for a moment on the laws of development which Meumann, at the end of the first volume, derives from his preceding investigations concerning the child and its faculties. He considers it impossible to summarize this developmental process under a single formula, as Pestalozzi attempted with his: from observation to concept, and W. Stern with his: from the periphery to the center. A child is, after all, always, from its birth, a product of its own disposition, which includes all sorts of faculties, and many external factors acting upon it. But according to Meumann, it is possible to draw some general lines along which development proceeds.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. also Meumann, Intelligenz und Wille 2nd ed. Leipzig, Quelle und Meyer 1913, p. 42 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: All these laws, according to Meumann, have great pedagogical significance. They teach us, for example, that variation and repetition must always go together in the teaching and education of the child; one must equally avoid the mistake of leaving everything in the child to its own development, as well as that of wanting to stereotype and mechanize everything in the child. Therefore, neither Rousseau nor Pestalozzi is right; the child must be developed according to its own disposition and nature, but that development should be influenced and guided by the education of others. Education should thus be both "naturgemäss" (in accordance with nature), insofar as it should adapt to the student and his peculiar gifts; and also "zielgemäss" (goal-oriented), insofar as it does not leave the development of the student to chance or whim, but leads it in fixed paths and directs it towards a goal.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Whoever avoids extremes in education and takes into account both the curriculum and the student, will heartily agree with most of these conclusions and reasonings of Meumann. But he will not be able to suppress the question whether he is now seeing discoveries of the new, empirical psychology and pedagogy. Were not all these so-called laws, in essence, known to all pedagogues at all times, and were they not even, more or less consciously, applied by all parents and teachers in the practice of life? Be that as it may, the old theory and practice received a strong confirmation from the exact investigation of the most recent times; they appear to be based on better observation and sounder reasoning than many today are willing to grant to the so-called conceptual and normative pedagogy.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: And so it is with all the faculties and powers of man; one can practice walking, jumping, gymnastics, boxing, enduring hunger and thirst, etc., and likewise perceiving, remembering, thinking, willing, etc., but everywhere one encounters a limit, because man is a finite and limited being. Fortunately, parents and teachers have a deep sense of this, for with the application of Meumann's abstract, intellectualistic theory, the children would be in a sad state.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ In Gutberlet, Experim. Psychologie, p. 249 ff. ¹ This example, taken from Meumann, proves how easily the proponents of empirical psychology and pedagogy can yet abandon the foundation of empirical research and lose themselves in speculation. Indeed, as soon as one does not merely observe and state the phenomena, but connects them and wants to reduce them to a principle or law, empiricism fails and thought, and with it the religious or philosophical worldview, comes to speak. This applies particularly to all psychic phenomena, from perception, memory, attention, intellect, reason, emotion, will, etc. Hence, the empiricist psychologists today differ from each other on all these things just as much as the practitioners of general psychology did before. Agreement is now much more sought after than in previous times.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: But apart from these remarks, the laws which Meumann formulates about the developmental course of the child's psychic life are few in number, and moreover very vague and general. Of course, the modesty that forbids saying more than can be justified is to be praised. But one may still ask whether the teacher and educator have so much to gain from the knowledge of them in practice. Certainly, the pedagogue needs general principles that can serve as a guide in the extensive field he has to cultivate; but Meumann promised at the beginning of his work that empirical pedagogy would enable the educator "to be clear at all times about the justification of his pedagogical measures." It seems that with these general laws, this is still far from being the case, at least as far as with the educational principles that a former pedagogy offered him.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: For he can learn those laws by heart, but he must apply them every moment in life and must for that purpose consult his own insight and judgment. Often he will, especially if he is an experienced teacher equipped with tact, hit the mark; but often he will also be at a loss with the complicated cases that occur in reality and will have to be content with a decision to the best of his knowledge. Almost nothing is changed in this if the teacher consults investigations that have been made into the developmental course of a special function, e.g., of memory, attention, imagination, thinking power, will, etc. For not only do the opinions on this vary widely; but also here he, by the nature of the case, only gets knowledge of some general laws that govern the development of those special functions, and thus he remains called upon to form a judgment according to those general laws about the particular case he faces in life.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: This remark is by no means intended as a reproach, for it is to be considered a privilege and a blessing that in education so much depends on the personality of the educator. But the remark does prove that empirical pedagogy can by no means, starting from the student, answer all pedagogical questions, nor make the educator certain at all times of the basis of his pedagogical measures. Just as empirical pedagogy may not misjudge the influence that the curriculum should have on teaching and education, it cannot eliminate the personality of the teacher and educator, who, however well-trained, has to act in each given case according to the circumstances.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Here too, we are not dealing with something entirely new. Teachers have long been able to assess their pupils intellectually, classifying them as clever, mediocre, or weak. This assessment is based on a series of experiences, but also often on a total impression received at the first acquaintance. Of course, such an assessment is provisional; it is not infallible and may later be modified; a wise teacher will therefore try to account for the data on which his judgment of a particular pupil rests. And if science makes efforts to base these assessments on a firmer foundation and to make them less dependent on subjective impressions, then such an endeavor deserves to be heartily applauded.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Binet, Les idées modernes sur les enfants 2nd ed., Paris, Flammarion 1911. Meumann, Experim. Pädag. II 2514 ff. Franz Weigl, Exper. Pädag. der Begabungsdifferenzen, p. 47 ff. ² Meumann, op. cit., II² 379, 524 ff. ³ Meumann, Intelligenz und Wille 2nd ed., pp. 421 ff. Lamers, Psychologie van het geheugen, Nijmegen, Malmberg, p. 11. ⁴ Meumann, Exper. Pädag. II² 535, Karl Groos, Das Seelenleben des Kindes, p. 133. Braunshausen, Einführung in die experim. Psychologie, Leipzig, Teubner 1915. Gutberlet, Experim. Psychologie, p. 45 ff. Lamers, Psychologie van het geheugen, p. 104.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. on the concept of type: Stern, Die differentielle Psychologie, p. 158 ff. ¹ Binet, Les idées modernes sur les enfants, p. 209.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Stern, Die differentielle Psychologie, p. 318 ff., 327 ff., 449. Id., Die Jugendkunde, p. 48 ff. Meumann, Experim. Pädag. II² 26 ff., 127.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: If psychography is to fulfill this task, all sorts of changes must be made in the school and all sorts of novelties introduced. What currently exists of it is, in fact, defective and highly insufficient. In the first place, therefore, a list must be kept in every school for every child, in which everything is recorded that is important for the knowledge of the child in all its peculiarities, as is now already done with feeble-minded, inferior, and criminal children, etc. Secondly, such a list must be arranged systematically and methodically; and it is the task of the practitioner of psychography to indicate the viewpoints and to establish the methods according to which the investigation of the individuality must be undertaken and the list for each child must be filled in. Such a scheme received the name of psychogram, by which is therefore to be understood, according to Stern, the application of the psychographic method indicated for a specific individual.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Such psychograms have been drawn up in great variety by many scholars, e.g., for adults and later also for children by the professors Heymans and Wiersma, and then in particular an extensive psychographic scheme by Stern, Lipmann, and Baade, which was supplemented by the Russian psychiatrist Lasurski, and in which a systematic list of characteristics is given that must be investigated for the knowledge of an individual.¹ Psychography is then given the task of conducting an investigation into school work and its results, into the strength and duration of attention, into the different gifts and activities of the intellect, of memory, imagination, thinking power, abstracting, combining, and criticizing, into the desire for work in free hours, into the preference for one or another subject, into special talents, into the relationship with and interaction with others, etc., etc.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Stern, Die differentielle Psychologie, pp. 318 ff., 327 ff., 449. Id., Die Jugendkunde, pp. 48 ff. Meumann, Experim. Pädag. II² 26 ff., 127.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Stern has felt this objection and has therefore already repeatedly expressed the idea—and behold a third novelty demanded by psychography—that in every city, next to the school doctor, a school psychologist should be appointed, who can give guidance to the investigation of individuality. Although he found much opposition, he did not give up his idea. It is also entirely in line with psychography. For it cannot be expected of the teacher in general that he be a psychologist and can conduct an independent and complete investigation into the individuality of each of his pupils. In any case, he needs guidance and help in this. And this must therefore be provided to him by the school psychologist, who has to ensure that individuality lists are established and maintained in every school; who must give the necessary instructions for the investigation of the pupils' properties, and who finally must collect, process, and profit from all this psychographic material for his advice.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Stern, Die differentielle Psychologie, pp. 338 ff. and the literature cited there in the bibliography, pp. 380 ff. Meumann, Exper. Pädag. II² 27 ff. Ruttmann, Hauptergebnisse der Psychologie. Leipzig, Wunderlich 1914. Heymans, Psychologie der vrouwen, pp. 287 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: But this work is again so extensive and heavy that a school psychologist cannot take it on in its entirety. Therefore, Stern posits as a fourth demand that there should be various institutes in the country for the study of the psychology of youth. In Leipzig and Munich, in Hamburg and Bremen, a beginning has already been made with this. But private initiative falls short for this gigantic task. Therefore, the state must take this interest upon itself, and establish institutions at all universities and also elsewhere in large cities and connect the necessary workforce to them, who devote themselves entirely to this Jugendkunde (youth science); process the immense material that has been collected on thousands and thousands of children, and thereby try to arrive at a psychography of all children of the nation, at a reliable psychological statistic of all citizens of the country, at a kind of human studbook, as one now already possesses for horses and cattle.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Stern, Die Jugendkunde, pp. 71 ff. ² Stern, Die Jugendkunde, pp. 32 ff. Aloys Fischer, Aufgabe und Entwicklung des deutschen Schulwesens nach dem Kriege. Leipzig, Klinkhardt 1916, p. 40. Gutberlet, Philosophisches Jahrbuch 1917, 2nd issue, pp. 133 ff. ³ Van der Waerden, Het Taylorstelsel, Amsterdam, "Ontwikkeling" 1916. A. W. Sanders, Het Taylorstelsel. De arbeiders en de komende vrede. Deventer, Kluwer 1917. David de Kok, "Het Taylor-systeem," De Katholiek, March 1917, pp. 178-190.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Psychography thus leads back to psychotechnics. For if we in this way obtain a statistic, on the one hand, of the gifts and talents that lie dormant in the younger generation, and on the other hand, of the number and nature of the professions that are practiced in society, then it becomes possible to establish a connection between the two and to organize the training of the youth in such a way that it pursues and achieves a concrete goal. At present, all this happens for a large part unconsciously, and much is left to arbitrariness and chance, as a result of which much strength is lost. How many are there not in contemporary society who have missed their career, or do not practice a profession at all! All that can be different and better if we break with all haphazard theories, rationalize all labor, and base all teaching, education, and training on a scientific basis.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. also Bebel, Die Frau, p. 288. ² W. Stern, Die Jugendkunde, p. 35. G. Budde, Moderne Bildungsprobleme, Langensalza, Beyer 1912, pp. 32 ff., 55 ff. ³ Budde, op. cit., pp. 19 ff., 37 ff. Id., Die Wandlung des Bildungsideals in unserer Zeit 2nd ed., Langensalza 1912, pp. 90-101.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Indeed, Darwin's theory of evolution pointed in the same aristocratic direction, insofar as it assigned a privileged place to the strongest organisms in the struggle for existence, and assured them, through natural and sexual selection, in conjunction with the inheritance of acquired characteristics, a continuous, ever-rising development. The study of heredity, which was taken up again with this, moreover, placed in the clearest light that the inequality among people by no means originates from the outside, but is present in individuals from birth, not only physically in health and strength, but also mentally in disposition and gifts.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: As a result of this reversal, there was soon almost no one left who upheld the theory of the mental equality of all people; everyone abandoned the doctrine of the tabula rasa and returned to the old confession of the natural, original inequality of people, both in psychic and in physical respects. But in connection with the aforementioned democratization of the school, the conclusion is drawn from these changed insights that one must apply the principle of selection to the children in the school as radically and consistently as possible. For, on the one hand, a leveling effect emanates from modern culture; all difference in status and rank, in authority and office, is disappearing more and more; there is political equality, and this sooner or later has social equality as a consequence; the opposition of the classes, which now still exists in such a sharp form in many respects, is evil and should disappear as soon as possible.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Likewise, he desires that, with the introduction of the general public school, ragged and unclean children, when warnings, threats, and punishment of the parents are of no avail, be taken from the parents and placed with private individuals or in institutions. The interest of the child and that of the state demand this. But he is of the opinion that a great influence on cleanliness can be exerted by the school baths, as they already do in various places. But for that, it is necessary that the school bath be given full citizenship. Here we are still fiercely debating it; in Baden and Bavaria, in Switzerland, there is hardly a school, at least in the large cities, where there are no school baths." And with De Amsterdammer of October 14, 1900, he wishes that when new schools are built, there will be no more talk about it, for it goes without saying that school baths are made in them, they belong there just as much as classrooms.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Despite all this, Mr. Roosma still belongs to the moderates. The introduction of free education has so far been impossible in his opinion, because under the still valid primary education law it would mean privileging public education. However, as soon as the equalization of public and private education has been achieved, there will be no obstacle to the introduction of free education. It is still something new in this country, but it already exists elsewhere in many countries, especially in America; and it will in due time also be introduced in our fatherland, although an immediate introduction would certainly bring with it difficulties at present. Mr. Roosma thus takes into account the private school, accepts its equalization with the public one, and does not speak a word of a compulsory neutral state school for all children of the nation. Mr. Ceton, however, sounds a very different note, as the spokesman for a not so small group in the social-democratic party.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Ceton, Sociaaldemocratie en Onderwijs (Social Democracy and Education), reprinted from De Nieuwe Tijd of Dec. 1913, Jan. and Feb. 1914.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: It is true that Mr. Troelstra attributes the victory, achieved in the revision of Art. 192 of the Constitution, especially to his party, and to the changed attitude that it adopted in the Groningen motion of 1902 with regard to the school question. Indeed, this Groningen motion was a remarkable moment in the developmental history of the social-democratic party in this country. But one should not be deceived by it with regard to the freedom-loving intentions that are cherished in this party.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Quoted in the Nieuwe Provinciale Courant of Jan. 22, 1902. and an article on "Verkiezingen" by Mr. J. de Vries of Mildam, in Het Schoolblad of July 19, 1917.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Quoted in the Nieuwe Provinciale Courant of Feb. 22, 1917, and an article on "Verkiezingen" by Mr. J. de Vries of Mildam, in Het Schoolblad of July 19, 1917. ³ Among others, also J. P. Lotsy, De wereldbeschouwing van een natuuronderzoeker, in verband met de voorgestelde wijziging van art. 192 der Grondwet. The Hague, Nijhoff 1917, and Fred. van Eeden, in De Amsterdammer of June 2, p. 2.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Now one can heartily agree with this, insofar as nothing else is meant by it than that society or the state must provide for sound and sufficient education in all places of the country for all children of the nation. But in the demand for free unified schools, there is a great deal of exaggeration. One readily appeals to America for this,¹ but this appeal has little force: the school system there arises from social life, the school is not a government school imposed on the people, but truly a people's school, managed by school boards, as a rule elected by the people themselves, and from school funds, which are formed from a special school tax.²
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. R. A. van Sandick, Democratische opvoeding, Studies in Volkskracht, Serie II no. 11 and 12, Haarlem, Bohn 1915, also cited by Mr. Roosma. ² Cf. A. J. Schreuder, in Paedagogisch Tijdschrift. Groningen, Noordhof. VIII issue 5-6.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Thus G. Friedrichs in the Monatshefte für Volkserziehung, publications of the Comenius-Gesellschaft, according to the Handelsblad of Dec. 6, 1916, Morning edition.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: There is more, however. From the unified school, one expects rapprochement, appreciation, perhaps even greater equalization of the classes among themselves. But that is again reckoned without reality. It is true that children from different classes, in and out of school, as well as children of different sexes, often interact freely and uninhibitedly. But that is not so much thanks to the school as to the age they are in, in which class consciousness has not yet developed in them. As soon as they approach the years of puberty, that begins to change; and then it turns out that the school by no means controls life. On the contrary, the class difference that exists in society works through into the school, among the pupils of the gymnasium and higher civic school, among the students of a university, and in all layers and circles of social life.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: The striving for a unified school seems all the more strange as it arises at a time when differential psychology has come into being and pedagogy insists on an individualizing education. Psychology informs us of the existence of very different talents, abilities, types, and characters among pupils, and contemporary pedagogy demands that one take this into account in teaching, and differentiate the classes and schools accordingly. We must return to this briefly later; but here it should be pointed out in a few words the turn in ideas that this newer pedagogy has brought about regarding coeducation.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. Coeducatie. Pro: J. A. Waldorp-van der Togt. Contra: A. J. Schreuder, Baarn 1916.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Cf. Coeducatie. Pro: J. A. Waldorp-van der Togt. Contra: A. J. Schreuder, Baarn 1916. ² Just like others, Mr. A. H. Gerhard has also come to different thoughts regarding the general freeness of primary education. Whereas he previously defended it, he is now of the opinion that its introduction under the existing circumstances does not promise beneficial consequences, would not bring about the disappearance of class differences, and need not necessarily be accompanied by compulsory education. See the quotation in an article on "Education according to giftedness" by Mr. J. Stout in Het Schoolblad of July 19, 1917, which lists many objections to the unified school.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Of much more importance are the bureaus for vocational choice, which have been established in recent years in numerous places, both outside and inside our country.² Many parents nowadays are at a loss as to what their children should become; they cannot judge the disposition and peculiar talents of their children, and are also not aware of the requirements, both physical and mental, set by the various professions; they know little about the state of supply and demand in any profession, and the choice is difficult for them as to which school provides the best training for a particular profession. Our society is becoming so complicated and training so specialized that information and advice are desirable and necessary in many cases.³
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² See my Opvoeding der rijpere jeugd, p. 176 ff. ³ Prof. Heymans, De toekomstige eeuw der Psychologie, pp. 11-12, points out that we, although we may think much more about it, find it so much more difficult to find our place in the world than the members of a previous generation, hence our uncertainty, our swaying back and forth, our frequent mistakes in making the great life choices: profession, spouse, friends, religious and political direction. Since the year 1850, the number of divorces per 1000 married couples has risen from 0.15 to 0.75, the number of separations from bed and board from 0.04 to 0.20; and a survey conducted by Heymans and Wiersma showed that of the men of the previous generation 30%, of those of the present, despite their young age, no less than 12% had already repeatedly changed profession.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ See above, p. 20. Stern, Die Jugendkunde, p. 25. Indeed, Bebel said in his work on Die Frau und der Sozialismus 16th ed., Stuttgart 1892, p. 290, that a person owes everything he is to society: "was also immerhin Einer ist, das hat die Gesellschaft aus ihm gemacht" (whatever one is, society has made him that).
author: Herman Bavinck

text: One must indeed be amazed at the confidence with which many want to entrust vocational choice to specially established bureaus. It is connected with the worldview already discussed above, that leadership in contemporary society has passed from blind, irrational nature into the hands of the intelligent, wise human; and that the whole of life in its depth and scope should be rationalized and socialized. Of socialization, however, there is, properly considered, no question at all here, because, as was just remarked, the whole change consists in the fact that the influence and decision are taken away from the parents and the person concerned himself and entrusted to a college of officials. And rationalization has its advantages in some cases, but also very certainly its disadvantages, especially when it concerns vocational choice.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: For, persons who serve to provide information and advice in this matter will likely be inclined to place the most emphasis on intellectual gifts, since these naturally attract attention first and are most clearly observable. In this process, the moral qualities, which in themselves and for numerous professions have much greater value, will involuntarily recede and occupy only the second or third rank. One cannot easily control them, and is unable to judge the inner life, the disposition, and the heart. Thus one arrives at an intellectualization of social life, which in the present time should rather be counteracted than promoted, and one runs the risk of populating the higher schools more than is desirable, and of giving rise to an unfortunate learned proletariat; to which is added that in by far the most cases, one does no service to children by detaching them from the social milieu in which they were born and raised.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ See above, p. 49. ² According to Goddard, out of 2000 schoolchildren, 75% were normally gifted, 21% below-normal, and only 3% more than ordinarily gifted. (in Meumann, Experim. Pädag. II² 298.)
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Although it has been many years since Bebel wrote these words, his ideal still captivates many to this day. The development of modern technology contributes its share to this. The monotonous, joyless, mind-numbing labor in the factories awakens the desire for shorter working hours and more hours for relaxation and rest; the glorification of labor, to which Bebel gave expression in the words: ohne Arbeit kein Genuss, keine Arbeit ohne Genuss (no pleasure without work, no work without pleasure), has in broad circles made way for the demand for the right to idleness.² And on the other hand, love for this ideal is cultivated because it will promote equality among the citizens of society, and bring head and hand labor closer together.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Paul Lafargue, The Right to be Lazy. Translated by J. de Wachter, Amsterdam, Emmering 1916.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: It goes without saying that this conception of the citizen's task in the future society had to have an influence on teaching and education, and in particular had to give a much broader place to labor in the curriculum. For labor, so we are taught from the social-democratic side, first lets us know the essence of things, and must therefore be the foundation of teaching and education. In the schools, above all, labor education is necessary, which provides knowledge of the labor process and teaches how to handle tools. All children should therefore be formed mentally, but also physically and technically; they must all learn to work.¹ And what is demanded by social-democratic principles finds support in the developmental course of modern culture and is promoted by the practice of life. For in it, it became more and more apparent that what mattered were men and women whose arms and hands were not wrongly attached to their bodies, but who knew how to manage and could pave their own way.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Ceton, Sociaal-democratie en onderwijs, p. 9 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² See my: Paedagogische Beginselen, Kampen, J. H. Kok 1904, p. 116. Cf. also Niebergall, "Staatsbürgerliche Erziehung," in Recht, Verwaltung und Politik im neuen Deutschland, edited by Alfred Bozi and Hugo Heinemann. Stuttgart, Enka 1916, pp. 289-304.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ See above, p. 16 ff. ² Cf. Dr. Franz Kuypers, Volksschule und Lehrerbildung in den Vereinigten Staaten, Leipzig, Teubner 1907, p. 45 ff. ³ Kerschensteiner, Der Begriff der staatsbürgerlichen Erziehung 3rd ed. Leipzig, Teubner 1914. Id., Grundfragen der Schulorganisation 3rd ed. Leipzig, Teubner 1912. Peters, Einführung in die Pädagogik. Leipzig, Teubner 1901, p. 55 ff. My Opvoeding der rijpere jeugd, p. 201 ff. S. S. in De School met den Bijbel, Jan. 25, 1917 and ff. J. Bruinwold Rieder, De lagere school op nieuw-opvoedkundigen grondslag III. De schoolhervorming in Duitschland. (De werkschool tegenover de voormalige leerschool). Amsterdam, van Looy 1912, which also mentions literature at the end.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: This contrast, however, is to be called less accurate from the start. For what Kerschensteiner, with some disdain, calls the "learning school," does not in itself exclude the labor, self-activity, and activism of the pupil. It is true that the learning school in former times, in connection with the whole character of the culture of that time, regarded the pupil as a disciple, who had to absorb the subject matter more or less passively. But the learning school too has moved with the times, has profited from the better insights of modern pedagogy, and is continuously extending its reforms to all subjects. And it can do this, because according to its own nature, it by no means excludes the self-activity and labor of the pupils, provided that by labor one does not exclusively think of manual labor.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Manual labor is, however, only one of the many forms of labor; there is also a labor of the mind, of intellect, emotion, and will, of memory, imagination, and judgment. And this labor is by no means excluded from ordinary, even primary, education. In reading, writing, arithmetic, and likewise in the teaching of language, history, geography, the children are by no means purely passive, nor do they need to be; although it is true that they cannot be active in the same degree and in the same way in the different subjects. Conversely, the pupils in a so-called work or labor school cannot be purely active; they too are pupils, must receive instruction, and need guidance. This applies, of course, in the first place to the ordinary subjects of education, which one, to know them, simply has to learn; but it also applies to actual manual labor, in which, if it is not to degenerate into useless tinkering, instruction and example, advice and guidance are indispensable.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: In the question of the learning school versus the work school, it is not so much about the contrast expressed in these names, but about another contrast. It is the struggle between the old and the new educational ideal. According to the first, people in former times were of the opinion, and could in good faith be of the opinion, that a child who only attended primary school and then entered life was sufficiently prepared if it could read, write, and do some arithmetic; for all that was necessary to know for the exercise of some profession, it learned in the workshop. And the pupils who, after primary school, attended a secondary school, received an education entirely in the humanistic spirit. But times have changed; this education is now no longer sufficient, for almost any profession and for any position; life now sets different and higher demands.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: One can, with Rein, distinguish mainly three groups of classes in contemporary society: the lower, middle, and higher professional strata. The first comprises the workers, small farmers, etc., and nowadays needs not only general developmental education in primary school, but also, to an increasing extent, lower vocational education thereafter; the second group includes the small middle class, shopkeepers, small traders, larger farmers, etc., and needs continued general developmental education and thereafter intermediate vocational education; and the third group, consisting of large merchants, large landowners, higher officials, officers, scholars, etc., must, after primary school, receive education at a higher civic school or gymnasium, and thereafter at a university (for agriculture, commerce, military academy, technical university, etc.) or university.¹
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ W. Rein, "Schulorganisation der Zukunft" in the above-cited work by Bozi and Heinemann, pp. 305-316.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Cf. my Opvoeding der rijpere jeugd, p. 204. The feelings in this country are also still very divided about the desirability of introducing manual labor as a compulsory subject in all primary schools, cf. an article on: "Handenarbeid in de school" by Frits van Raalte in the Algemeen Handelsblad of May 29, 1917.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: This does not mean a so-called harmonious formation of all faculties and powers in all directions for all people. For this is impossible; every education that reckons with reality, that is, with the own nature and destiny of the pupils, is one-sided and steers in a certain direction. The differentiation in life should be respected in the school; not everything that is good is suitable for all people at all times. Therefore, Bebel's demand that every scholar and artist must perform physical labor for a part of the day is absurd,¹ unless by this labor a walk or some other relaxation is perhaps understood. The reverse, that a laborer should have to be a scholar or an artist, sufficiently shows the folly of the demand. And the appeal to great men like da Vinci, Cellini, and Lincoln, who excelled in so many respects, carries no weight for the average person. Among these, the man of twelve trades and thirteen misfortunes is not particularly well-regarded.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Even the unified school, properly conceived, does not exclude differentiation according to the pupils' comprehension and likewise according to the distinct local conditions.² In every country, after all, the school, both primary and secondary, takes on its own character, in Germany and France just as much as in England and America. Emile Boutroux even recently tried to show that the Idea of the Whole was a great German thought, which has given rise to masterpieces in metaphysics, poetry, music, but has also seduced the Germans to set as the final goal of education the conquest and domination of the world. And so, even within one's own country, thoughts differ greatly as to which subject should be in the foreground in school; Kerschensteiner, for example, emphasizes national education, Kabisch historical education, Foerster moral education. There is a diversity of gifts, let this then also come into its own in teaching and education!
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ² Ziegler, Allgemeine Pädagogik, p. 123 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: ¹ Münsterberg, Grundzüge der Psychotechnik, p. 531 ff.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Münsterberg somewhere makes a distinction between making a person the object of our physiological or psychological investigation, and dealing with him as a human being. In the first case, he is for us an object, in a certain sense a thing or an object, in the second case he meets us in his entirety, with his own individuality, as a person, as an I-ness, and we can only get to know him through sympathy and love. The essential and real in man is indeed unattainable with the empirical, experimental method and inaccessible to exact science; it is "ineffable," because it cannot be analyzed, but can only be grasped and known in its entirety, synthetically. Therefore, alongside the most accurate psychography, biography retains its value, alongside intellect, intuition, alongside knowledge, love. And knowledge often puffs up, but love builds up.
author: Herman Bavinck

text: Pastor sounded more relational than functional, more affectionate than authoritarian.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I was a pastor long before I knew I was a pastor; I just never had a name for it. Once the name arrived, all kinds of things, seemingly random experiences and memories, gradually began to take a form that was congruent with who I was becoming, like finding a glove that fit my hand perfectly--a calling, a fusion of all the pieces of my life, a vocation: Pastor.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I don't love the rampant consumerism that treats God as a product to be marketed.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I wonder if at the root of the defection is a cultural assumption that all leaders are people who "get things done," and "make things happen."...But while being a pastor certainly has some of these components, the pervasive element of our two-thousand-year pastoral tradition is not someone who "gets things done" but rather the person placed in the community to pay attention and call attention to "what is going on right now" between men and woman, with one another and with God--this kingdom of God that is primarily local, relentlessly personal, and prayerful "without ceasing."
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I want to insist that there is no blueprint on file for becoming a pastor. In becoming one, I have found that it is a most context-specific way of life: a pastor's emotional life, family life, experience in the faith, and aptitudes worked out in an actual congregation in the neighborhood in which she or he lives--these people just as they are, in this place. No copying.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: Pastor Maybe: given the loss of cultural and ecclesiastical consensus on how to live this life, none of us is sure of what we are doing much of the time, only maybe.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: William Faulkner was once asked how he went about writing a book. His answer: "It's like building a chicken coop in a high wind. You grab any board or shingle flying by or loose on the ground and nail it down fast." Like becoming a pastor.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: I am a pastor. My work has to do with God and souls--immense mysteries that no one has ever seen at any time. But I carry out this work in conditions--place and time--that I see and measure wherever I find myself, whatever time it is.
author: Eugene Peterson

text: On one of these evenings he was asked by one of the students something about preaching. Something on the order of "What is the most important thing you do in preparing to preach each Sunday?" I think we were all surprised by the answer, at least I was. His answer: "For two hours every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon, I walk through the neighborhood and make home visits. There is no way that I can preach the gospel to these people if I don't know how they are living, what they are thinking and talking about. Preaching is proclamation, God's word revealed in Jesus, but only when it gets embedded in conversation, in a listening ear and responding tongue, does it become gospel."

If so-called worshippers didn't "get anything out of it," there had been no worship worth coming back for. text: Paul indicates that the risen Jesus not only appeared to individuals and small groups, but he also appeared to five hundred people at once, most of whom were still alive at the time of his writing and could be consulted for corroboration. Paul's letter was to a church, and therefore it was a public document, written to be read aloud. Paul was inviting anyone who doubted that Jesus had appeared to people after his death to go and talk to the eyewitnesses if they wished. It was a bold challenge and one that could easily be taken up, since during the Pax Romana travel around the Mediterranean was safe and easy. Paul could not have made such a challenge if those eyewitnesses didn't exist.
author: Unknown

text: Also, as Wright argues, the empty tomb and the accounts of personal meetings with Jesus are even more historically certain when you realize they must be taken together. If there had been only an empty tomb and no sightings, no one would have concluded it was a resurrection. They would have assumed that the body had been stolen. Yet if there had been only eyewitness sightings of Jesus and no empty tomb, no one would have concluded it was a resurrection, because people's accounts of seeing departed loved ones happen all the time. Only if the two factors were both true together would anyone have concluded that Jesus was raised from the dead.

text: That's why Courtland Allen started Indie Hackers: to create a community where people could pool knowledge and resources to help one another build online businesses. author: Anne-Laure Le Cunff

text: In ancient Greece, learning in public was woven into everyday life. To acquire new knowledge, you ventured into the bustling agora, the public square. There, elders shared their wisdom with small crowds, and you could join animated debates between scholars. To propose a new philosophical the-ory, you presented it openly in the polis, subjecting it to public scrutiny and critique. This offered the chance to refine ideas, but also the risk of public shame if your logic proved faulty. Beyond political debates, tradespeople peddled new business ideas and products. Inventors demonstrated proto-types, inviting feedback. Progress came not just from solitary thought but from the creative friction of diverse viewpoints colliding.
author: Anne-Laure Le Cunff

text: By nature, experiments are imperfect. They can also be a bit scary. However, iterating in public creates a culture of learning around yourself. A scholar might blog about their research to get real-time feedback from peers. A startup founder might build a scrappy version of their product to gauge demand. A designer could publish rough sketches. In each case, putting forward unpolished ideas sparks an ongoing dialogue, to reveal any gaps and iterate rapidly.
